quickSteps: Start with intent: decide whether you want to acquire XMR, spend it, or learn basics before you click anything.
Use a curated directory for discovery, then switch to execution mode and stop browsing.
Verify the execution entry point carefully, then double-check the receiving address before sending funds.
Ignore unsolicited helpers and any request for secrets or remote access, no matter how urgent it sounds.
After receiving XMR, choose your next step deliberately: secure storage first, then explore real use cases.

recoveryDecisionTree.title: If something feels off mid-swap
recoveryDecisionTree.goal: Avoid panic actions and reduce the chance of a second mistake.

branches.if: You have not sent funds yet
then: Re-enter through your trusted discovery path and verify the domain carefully.
Only proceed when the pair and receiving address are confirmed.

branches.if: You already sent the deposit and are waiting
then: Do not start a second swap out of impatience.
Record the basics: time, amounts, transaction ID, expected payout details.
Use official support paths only and share public details only.

branches.if: Someone offers help in DMs or asks for remote access
then: Never share seed phrase, private keys, or device access.
Continue only with official channels and your own verification routine.

branches.if: You suspect your device or wallet setup is compromised
then: Stop all new actions and isolate the risk.
Move funds using a clean-device workflow and a fresh wallet if needed.
Treat the issue as security hygiene first, then resume swapping later.

riskNotes: Verified style labels are a trust signal, not a guarantee. Always verify the domain and the receiving address before sending.
The highest-risk moment is before the first send. Reduce tab chaos and avoid search ads when possible.
Never accept help that asks for secrets or remote access. Public transaction details are enough for legitimate support.
Do not start a second swap in panic if a deposit is pending. Gather facts first and use official channels.
Follow local laws and regulations in your jurisdiction. Privacy tools are not the same as breaking rules.
